DIV1.HEAD:
S. Editha (Dialect von Wiltshire) aus Ms. Cotton Faustina B III.
Diese Legende ist bereits edirt von Black u. d. T. Chronicon Vilodunense, 1830. Dem Dichter dieser Legende gehört auch die von S. Etheldrede in dems. Ms. fol. 260 ff. (ed. in A. L. N. F. p. 282 ff.) an.
Im Ms. sind y und þ oft vertauscht, so 21 yat, ye st. þat, þe, 50 þnne st. ynne, 58 þwþs st. ywys u. a. Black in s. Ed. behält die Schreibweise des Ms. — Auf fol. 194 u. 5 ist oft corrigirt und radirt v. a. H.

LG.L: Almyȝty god in trinite, | fader & sone and holy goste,
Helpe and spede and conselle me, | as þou art god of myȝtus moste,spede aus rede corr.
And ȝeue me grace to brenge | to godde heyndynge,
Jhesu, for seint Edus sake, | þys werke, þat y, so vnconnynge,Edus in Edys corr.
Presumpswysly(che) haue vndere-take.in lyche ist che ausra|dirt.
For y considere and knowe welle hytte,
þat thyngus þat haue ben fer (I)-pastehinter fer sind zwei Buchst. ausradirt, vor past ein Buchst. (I); a. R. steht hertherto.
Leyȝtely(che) slydyth from monny(s) wytte,in lyche ist che ausra|dirt.mōnys in mannys corr. Ms. urspr. whytte, h ist ausradirt.
Bote ȝif þey ben in story (y)-wryton or caste;y ist ausradirt.
Wherfore y thenk in story to wryȝteMs. thenk, e in y corr.
Of kingus þat haue (y)-ben herbyforey ist ausradirt.Ms. byfore u. ybore mit n nach r überschr. (byforne, yborne).
Here in Westesexe, to touche a lyte,vor lyte sind zwei Buchst. ausrad. u. ly aufgetragen.
Seyȝthe kynge Egbert(e) was furste y-bore.Ms. byfore u. ybore mit n nach r überschr. (byforne, yborne).furste in fyrste corr.
For sump tyme in Westesexe þere was a kinge,in kinge ist i in y corr.
Egberte was þat kynges name,e in Egberte über Rasur überschr. kynges in kyngys corr.Cronica Cistrensis.
A douȝty knyȝt and of godde gouernynge,
And a mon he was of ryȝt godde fame.
þys douȝty knyȝt Egbert, Alquimundy (ys) sone,ys ist ausrad. u. an Alquimundy s angehängt.
To þe kyngdome of Westsex was corond kyngeMs. corone? in crownyd corr.
In þe ayȝte hundreth ȝere saue on
After þat Jhesu of Mary ded sprynge;ded in dyd corr.
And also he was þe twolthe kyngevor also ist after ausgestr.
þat in Westsex cristyndam nome
After Kyngylf, þat holy thynge,
þat by seynt Byryn crystyn be-come.
And at Wynchester y-cronyd he was
Of Elmestone, þat was bysshoppe þo.
& þe thryd ȝere after thoro goddys gracean thoro ist w angehängt.
Seynt Swythyn was I-bore also.Ms. bore in borne corr.
Byfore his tyme in Bretayne þer were
Syxe kyngdomus more þen his;
Bot foure þis kyng knytte y-fere,
As in trewe story wryten hit is.
þe kyngdam of Kent he wonne firste,in kyngdam ist a in o corr.
Wt mony a batelle strong and sore,
And drof owte þe kyng, þat he neuer dirste
Chalange þat kyngdam after more;
þe kyngdam of þe Marche he wonne also,
þis douȝty knyght Egbert þe kynge,
And þe kyngdam of Exsex he wonne þerto:
And hade þuse foure in his gouernynge.
And also by-fore his tyme y-wys
þis lond was clepyt alle-hole Bretayne,
þat now Englond y-clepyt ys
For kynge Egberd þat name dede downe layne.
Fiue moner of pepull here dwellyd þo,dwelt in dwellyd corr.
To wex þe Bretones for hurre synne:
Pictis, and Scottys, and Hyrysshe also,
And þe Denmarkes come þo first ynne,
And þe Saxsones were þo clepud ynne alsotilge þo.
In kyng Wortynger is tyme, hym to helpe;
And so þai deden hym seruice þo,
Bot how þay deden after, y nylt not ȝelpe.
For afterward þai drevyn þe Brytones houȝt
Fro herre owne habitacyone in þis lond here
And drevyn hem in-to Walys, wt-outen douȝte,Ms. hom?
& in-to þis day þay dwelle ȝet þere.
From Saxsonye in Almayne þer comen y-wys
Thre maner of pepulle of one tonge:
Saxones, & Jutys, and Englysshe,
þat thralles weren here fulle longe.
Bot afterward þey weren long lordys and kyngys hereCronica Cistrensis.
And hadden alle þis hole reme in her gouernaunce,
Tylle Wyllyam Bastard, as ȝe ȝet mowe yche day here,
Come owt of Normandy in Fraunce
And slow kyng Haralde in þe batelle of Hastynge,
And alle his ost he scomfytyd þere also;Ms. ōst = host?
And þo of alle Englonde he was y-cronyd kynge
And put þe Saxsones a-ȝeyn in to thraldam & wo.
Knyȝtes and swyers he made þo bounde,
þe wyche gentyls and lordys byfore þat were;
Dukys and herles he drof owte of þis lond —
þey durst not here abyde for fere —
And made mony of hom lordes þo
þat comen wt hym fro Normondy,
And put þe Saxsones aȝeyn in thraldam & wo
By-cause of here synne (&) of here foly —
For pryde, couetyse and lechery& fehlt im Ms.
God toke opon hem suche vengeaunce þus;
And falslyche to for-swere hem þey nere neuer wery —
Here owne kyng Haralde ȝaffe hom ensampulle of þis. —haralde überschr.
Bot kynge Egberde, of þe wyche I speke to ȝov of ȝere,
Vsede no poyntes of suche synnes ny of suche foly:
Wherfore he knytte foure kyngdomus y-fere,
And gouerned hem welle and fulle monfully.
Bot when he had brouȝt þo foure kindamus to hepe
And won þe cyte of Chester also,
He commaundede alle men to clepe
Alle his lond Englonde þo,
And he commandede his men also
To clepe alle þe Saxsones Englisshemen,Ms. saxsons.
And alle þe Britones þat were þere þo
To ben y-clepud Wallisshemen.
Britones were long I-clepud Cadwallesmen,
After Cadwalle þat was hure kynge;hure in there corr.
Bot Saxsones clepud hom ȝeyȝthen Walshemenhom in them corr.ȝeyȝthen = sythen.
By-cause of sherte spekynge.Engestis in Engistis corr.
And Saxsones were y-clepud Engestis men,
Englys and Jutys bothe y-fere,
For Hengestis was þe first duke of hem
And in to þis lond he dede hem lere;
For ryȝt as Walshemen token hure name
Of Cadwalle þat þo hure kyng wys,
Ryȝt so Englisshemen token hure nameMs. token token.
Of here owne duke Hengestis.Engestis in Engistis corr.
And þus Englonde toke first his name
In þe gode kyng Egbertys tyme,
Ryȝt as we clepe ȝet þe same
And herrafter shulde wt-ouȝte lyme.wt ist überschr.
And when kyng Egbert, as I sayde heyre,
Had set in pese þus alle his lond
And scomfidid his enmyes wt batel & monhode y-fere
& made alle þis reme to ben y-clepud alle-hole Englonde,
He satte þo in grete rest and peys:
For nomon durst wt hym werre —
For he was a monfulle knyȝt wt-ouȝte leys —
His name was knowe bothe neȝe and ferre.
For when he had þus foure kyngdamus to-geder satte,
He dwelte at Wyltone wt-ouȝte leys
Nyne wynter longe after þat
In gode rest & in gode peys.ist hinter 120 geschr.
And other-whyle at Wynchester he dwelte also,
And eke at Salisbury in þat tour,
And in mony other places mo,
As a kyng ouȝte of suche honour.
An holy mon, forsothe, he was,
And gret almys he dede for goddes sake;
Religyose houses in mony a plase
For goddys loue he let þo make.
In þe toune of Wyltone let make oneHenricus Crōpe.
In þe worshippe of owre lady,
By consel of Bysshop Elmestone,
þat was bysshop of Wynchester þo, sycurlye,
And threttene sustren he sette þere-Inne,
To serue þere god bothe nyght and day;
A Religiose house þey clepte hit þenne;A ist vorgeschr.
Seynt Mary chirche þerto þo laye.
For Elburwys loue he made þat place,
þat was þe erle of Wyltones wyf by-fore,
And kyng Egbertys sustre also he was,
And þere-inne also hee was y-bore; —
Erle Wolstones wyff, forsothe, hee was,
Or he toke þe mantelle and þe rynge;
And to make a relygiose house of hur owne place,
He prayede hur brother Egbert þe kynge.
Kyng Egbert grauntede hit anone
By conselle of Elmestone, as I sayde ȝere.
þis ordinaunce was þus y-done
Of his regnynge þe threttythe ȝere.
þis Religiose house was foundyd þere
þe threttythe ȝere of his regnynge,
And ayȝte hundryd and thretty ȝere
After þat Jhesu of Mary dud sprynge.
And seuene ȝere lenger ȝet left his lyffeHenricus Crōpe.
In his remys gouernynge, wt-ouȝte blame.
A sone he had by Osyth, his wyffe,Black left.
Atwolf was þat chyldis name.
Bot afterwarde, when he was ded,Ms. dede mit ausrad. e.
At Wynchester was his byryenge,
And Atwolf his sone, as I haue red,
Anone after was made her kynge.
þis Atwolf was croned kyng here
After þat goddis sone was bore
Ayȝte hundreth & ayȝte & thretty ȝere
And thre monethus & nyne dayes more.
Kyng Atwolff was an harlasmonMs. urspr. man, über a ist o übersch. harlas = harmless.
And loued ryȝt welle to serue god;
Forsothe, harme nolde he do none,
Bot he wold do meche gode.
þis kyng had in hys leuynge
Foure sones by hys weddyd wyff —
Osburwe he het, þat semely thynge,
Children had he nomo in alle his lyffe; —
After he was kynge, he wedded hure sone —
His owne spencers douȝter he was;
In Westsex he dwellyd þo alle-one
At Wylton in his owne place.
For Wyltone was a gode toune þo,
And meche pepulle þeder drowe,
þe kynge duellud þere meche also,
For plentythe of vitel þere was y-nowe.Bl. plentyche.
Hit was meche þe better for his sake,
For he was a fulle honest mone;
Chirches and Abbays he ded do make
Wt-inne his reme mony one.
And to holy chirche þis kyng ȝaff þan
þe tenthe part of his lond,
By conselle of seynt Swythan,
þat þo was bysshop of Wynchester, I vnderstonde.
þe religiouse house of Wyltone he encreset also
þe whiche his fader had I-made byfore,
And mo religiouse wymen he sette þerto,
& ȝaff londes and rentes welle more.
For men of holy chirche he loued fulle welle
And gret chere to hem euer he made;
And also, wt seynt Elmistone when he dede dwelle,
Ordour of sodekyn forsothe he hade —
For a mone of holychirche he wolde haue be,
Bot þe reme nold not consent þerto,Cronica Cistrensis.
For þere was non other heyre bot he —
For kynge Egberde had sones no mo.
Wherfore afterwarde he went to Rome
To Leo, þat was pope þere þanne,
To be assoyled of þat by his dome —
For þat was þe conselle of seynt Swythanne —
And wt hym he toke Alured his sone,
þat ȝongest was of hem alle,
And a twolmonthe at Rome he dud wone —
þe pope Leo men dede þo calle.
He graunted also þo to pay to Rome
Euery ȝere a peny y-wys
Of yche an house in his kyngdom —
þat "Peter pounse" y-clepud ȝet is.
For byfore his tyme þe lawe was suche:
þat, what mon had don ony opone horribulle synne,
As smytten his fader or mone of holy chyrche,
To þe pope he most go, his pardone to wynne;
I-fedryd to-gedere þey most þedur go,
Ryȝt as thewys gone to þe galowe-tre.
Kynge Athwolffe sawe hem oft so do,
And had of hem ryȝt gret pete.
þo he gate to Englond suche a priuilage
þat non Englysshemone shulde go more þeder in suche a manere;
He granted þo to þe Pope Leo suche a talage:
Offe euery howse in his kyndam a peny by ȝere.
Bot quen he had dwelled þere alle þat ȝere,
Home thoro Fraunce he come y-wys.
Kyng Charlys douȝter he weddede þo þere,
And in to Englonde wt hure y-comen he ys.Bl. come, Ms. comē.
He regned here two & twenty wyntre,
In grete worship and in gret prosperite;
He dyed and byreyd was at Wynchester.
Of þis plase byfore y-sayde þe secund founder was he.
Athelbalde his sone was mad kyng þo;
He regned here bot on ȝere, yche vnderstonde.Athelbaldus.
His owne stepmoder was wedded hym to,
Aȝeyns þe lawes of þis londe:
He wedded Judyth, þat was his fader wyffe.Cronica Cistrensis.
Wherfore alle thyng felle to hym a-mys;
He dyede for vengaunce of his synnefulle lyffe,
And at Shirburne y-buryed he ys.
And þen was Ethelbryt y-croned hure kyngeEthelbriȝtus.hure st. here.
Of alle Westsexus londe,
þe whyche was in his brother leuynge
Kyng of Kent, as I vnderstonde;
And regned after hym fyue ȝere ryȝt,
And had Westsex and Kent bothe yn fee;
And dyed þo thoro goddys myȝt,
And at Wymburne y-buryed was he.
Bot when Ethelbryȝt was þus forthe past,
Hys brother Etheldrede was y-croned þo kynge.Etheldredus.
Anone after þat in gret hast
Gret grace he hade thoro gode leuynge —
For an holy mon, forsothe, he was
And loued fulle welle goddys seruyse;
Euery day he wold here a masse,
As sone as he ded vp ryse; —
Wherfore hit fel hym oft by grace
To haue of god what þat he bedde.
In experience hit felle by case
At Asshedone, wase hath þe story redde:
For at Asshedone a tyme hit felle by case
þat Osegys, þat kyng of Denmarke was þo,
Come to Asshedone wt grete manasse,
Wt other lordys mony on mo.
Bot kyng Etheldrede was þere redy y-wys,
Wt Alured, his brother, and other mo,
Forto aȝeyn-stonde alle his malys
And to kepe þat countre fro hem also.
Herlyche in þe moretyde forsothe hit was
þat þis batel shuld þere ydo be.
Bot Etheldred went to chyrche a gode pas,
To here a masse þere of þe Trynite.
Bot þat whyle þe Danys in þe feld chesen hure place
Ryȝt at hure owne wylle;
Bot kyng Etheldred a-bode and herd his masse
And made his prayers knelyng fulle stylle.
Bote Alured his brother was in þe felde
Monfullyche wt alle his men,
Wel arayed wt spere and shelde;
þe mynstrals blwe hure trompus þen.
þus men bygonne & scarmysshute fast,
þe twey hostes bothe y-fere.
þe Englysshemen þey woxe a-gast
And bygunne to falle alle hure chere.
þe Englysshe lordys lokedone after hure kyng
And speke and prayden hym come to hem anone.
Bot he nold not þen for no-thynge,Ms. loke don.
Tyl alle þe masse were fully done.
Bot when þe masse was alle y-dee,
Kyng Etheldrede heyȝede hym fulle fast;
þe Englysshemen by-gonne to fle,Ms. dee, Bl. doe.
For þey were fulle sore a-gast.
þe kyng toke þo to hym his horse,
And in þe trinites holy name
He hym blessed and mad a crosse,
And bad his men to do þe same;
He prekede in to þe felde þo fulle snelle
Among þe Denmerkys so kene,
And alle þat he met adon he felle,Ms. adon oder adoū?
And slowe hem alle by-dene.
þe Dane kyng he slowe y-wys,
And alle his lordys þat were þere.
And þus þe victory was his,
þorowe help of þe trinite & of þe masse þat he dud here. —
By whyche ensawmpulle I may welle seeI st. ȝe.
How gracyose hit is a masse to here,
And nomlyche of þe trinite,
To euery worthy kyng or bachelere. —
Bot þen sone after dyed þis kyng
Etheldrede, þat was þe elder brothere,
þe ayȝthe ȝere of his regnynge.
Alured was heyre þo — þere nasse non othere. —Rex Alrudus.
Bot nowe y chulle ȝow telle by goddys grace
For whom ȝe ben y-holde to preyȝe fore
And who were first funders of þat place
Of þe whyche y spake of byfore.
In þe ayȝte hundreth after þe incarnacyone hit felle by case
þat Ethelmunde, þat of þe Marche þo was kynge,
Come in to Westsex wt gret manasse,
To make þe erle of Wylteshyre his vnderlynge.
Bot Wolstone, þat was erle of Wylteshyre þoo,
Aȝeynestode hym wt gret strenthe and mayne,
Wt mony a mon of Wylteshyre mo,
And drof hym to his lond aȝayne.
Bot in þat batelle was slawe y-wys
Alquimundy, þat holy mone, —
Erle Wolstonus wyffus fader he wys.fader übergeschr.
For hym he made gret soro and mone,
And for his soule a chyrche lette make
In Wyltone fast by his owne place,
To syng and red for his sowle sake;
þat a collage y-clepud þo hit wasse.
Bot in þe honour of owre lady
Hit had ben foundyd ferre byfore,
Bot thorow strong werre, securlye,
Hit was almost clene forlore.
And so for seynt Alquimoundyes loue hit was fyrst y-made
Off Walstone, þat was erle of Wylteshyre þo.
And afterwarde for Elburwys loue, as y ere sayde,
Kyng Egberde made þe religyose house þerto.
And so erle Walstone was furst founder of þat chirche
For seynt Alquimoundyes loue ywys,Henricus Crōpe.
And Elburwe þat religyose house let after whirche,
And so þe fyrst founder þerof he was, —
By consent of Egberde þe kynge,
þat was hure owne brother;
& so he was furst cause of þat house makynge —
He preyde hym so feyre, he myȝt non other,
Bot grauntede for (to) be hure patrone
And mayntenere of þat place.
And Elburwe hure-self dede þer-inne wōne,
Sone after þat þe erle ded was.
& kyng Egbert ȝaffe bothe londys & rente
To þat place and þe chirche, y-wys,
For his loue þat alle thyng sente;
And þus þe furst founder of kynges he ys.
And Atwolfe his sone, þat holy mon,
Ȝaff londys and rentys þerto, as y sayde ere.
And Ethelbalde his son, when he was gone,
Of kynges was þe thryd founder.
And kyng Ethelbryȝte, þat worthy knyȝt,
þe fourthe founder he was þerto.
And Etheldrede, þat holy wyȝte,
Was þe fyuethe founder also.
Of kyngys founders fynd I no mo
Y-wryton in no story y-wys —
Bot Wolstone and Elburwe þat weren þo
þe first causes off alle þis. —
Bot after Etheldrede Alured, his brother, was y-croned kynge,
þat was þe ȝongust brother of alle,
A fulle wysmon, and of fulle gode gouernynge —Cronica Cistrensis.
Alurde þe gode kynge, men dedon hym calle.
For quen he was a ȝonge thynge,
To Rome wt his fader he went,
And of Leo þe pope was anyntyd kynge —
þe gretter grace god hym sent.
þis Alrud lyued & regnyd kyng here
Nyne and twenty wyntre nyȝe,
In grete trauayle and werre y-fere —
þus Danes weren fulle fals and slyȝe
And werreden wt hym euer fulle fast;
Bot he was euer a douȝty knyȝt
And ouer-come hem at þe last,
þoro þe grace of goddys myȝt.
An holy mone forsothe was he
& seruede god bothe nyȝt and day,
For he dipartede hem (in) þree —
In what maner y chulle ȝow say.
Of foure and twenty houres y-wys
Ȝyf þe nombre be departyd in þre,
Eyȝte, eyȝte, and eyȝte hit ys —
Counte hit welle and ȝe mowe se.
þe first eyȝt houres of þe day
He serued god, heuene kynge,
þe secunde eyȝte houres in reste and play,
þe thryd eyȝte houres in his remes gouernynge.
Thre waxe-candels he let make þen,
Euery candelle y-leyche of weyȝt,
In his chapelle forto bren
Alle þe day and eke þe nyȝt:
þuse thre candels weren ordeyned þere
Forto depart þe tyme of þree
In maner ryȝt as I sayd ere,
As þe story telleth welle me.
Kyng Alured ȝet dude more þen þis:
He departed his rentys in two:
Hym-selfe þe to halfe and no more ywys,l. to(ke) þe?
þe toþer half in almys-dede was do:
To chirches and abbays þat weren pore
þe ton half þus ȝaffe he,
þay to haue hit for euermore
In possessyon and in fee.

And to Edgar he swore ryȝt þere

Vpone a day hit fell by case

In to a forest neyȝt to his place.
And when he come in to þat forestes syde,
A gret lust he had to slepe:
And vnder a tre he doune hym leyde.

Shalle regne here and in heuene blys

þe lamp, sone, þat is so bryȝt,
Signifyeth a douȝter þat ȝe shall haue,

And when þe quene had þus ysayde
And expoundyd þis sweuene ryȝt tys,
þe kyng hulte hym well a-payde
And mekelyche thongede þe kyng of blys.
þe kyng lay at Shaftusbury þo,
As þe story telleth welle me.
Bot to Wynchester he thoȝt to go,
Forto vysidete þat contre:
And toke his Jerney and forth con past
To-warde Wynchester, þat fayre cyte,
And come to Wyltone at þe last.
And a newe fayre chirche þere sawe he;
Bot when he was þere vpone þe doune,
þat chirche was lufty in his syȝt;
He thouȝt he wolde go doun to toune
And soiorne þere he thouȝt alle nyȝt.
Wt hym he toke a preuey mayneye
And to-warde þat chirche full sone he went,
For to se þat feyre abbey
And offerre þere in gode entent.
Bot to þat chirche when he come was,
Vp to þe auter he went anone an heyȝe,
For þere was made a ryal place
In þe worshepe of owre ladyȝe.

Sacryd maydenys and sustren y-fere,

Bot of hem þat seruede hym at þe borde
In þe story ys made no mensyone,
Ny of non other I speke no worde

For at þe lectron a mayde satte,
Wltrud was þat maydonus name,
A barones douȝter for sothe was þat

þat mayden red þat lesson þo,
Whyle þe kyng was atte mete.
þe kyng toke ryȝt gode hed þerto,
For hure voys was bothe myelde & swete,
An angelys voys hym thouȝt hit was:
And loke vp þat mayden vpone,
& for alle here veyle he seyȝe here face—
A feyrer hym thouȝt he sawe neuer none.
And so he thouȝt in his hert þo
þat he was a semely thynge;
And askede what kynradone he was come fro,
And also of here gode gouernynge.
"A Barones douȝter, my lorde, was he,
þat was a knyȝt of ryȝt gode fame
And dwelte here in þis countre,
Syre Godwyn was þat knyȝtis name.
Here fader ys dede, here moder also,
þis mayden here wt vs dothe dwelle,
To serue god here, as we shulle do;
Hit is holyche, my lorde, hure wylle.

To serue hure sustren wt alle mekenes,

For he couetede neuer in no wyse
To be worshepud for here heyȝe lynage,

So louyng & so lowelyche he was y-wys

And meyte and drynke he wold hem ȝeue,
For grace wt hure was euer y-nowe —
For þaw he ȝaff meche, y-nowe ȝet dud leue;

So vertuoselyche hurre lyff he ladde
& so furforthe he was forthe-fulte wt goddis grace,
þat euery mone of here Joy hadde

What for here deseruynge & hurre lynage,
Duke, Errelle & eke Barone
Wt all hurre faderes holle barnage
Putten hem-self vnder here subiectione.
And alle þe reme of Englond, bounde & fre,
Sayden þat he was worthy to bene a quene;
& quene of Fraunce he myȝt han be,
Bot he nolde neuer consent to bene.
þere nas no crystone kyng ny emperour,
Bysshop ny legate ny cardinalle,
þat þey nadde hure in gret honour,
& herre owne suster þey deden here calle.
Also þe pope, I vnderstonde,
þat was pope of Rome þo,
To hure send lettre in to Englonde
& his blessyng wt hem also.
Bot of worldelyche worshepe he toke none hedde,
Bot to serue god was alle here þouȝt
& þe pore and þe maymot forto clothe and fede —
Of oþer wordelyche honour ȝaff he ryȝt nouȝt.
For leuer here was þe pore to fede,
þe maymot, þe seke to wasshe & hele,
& blynd laȝerus & croked in chirche to lede

þen to han ben emperys of Rome

Or ellus quene of ony kyndome —
So meke and humble he was algate.
& euer he was fulle redy

& theuys y-dampnyde for felony
From þe Galoys he wolde hem lede;
To hurre fader he wolde ofto knele

þaw þey weron dampnyd in þat stounde.
For here fader was ryȝtwys to forthfulle þe lawe

Bot he nolde haue nomon y-slawe,
For he was so mercyfulle & so pytewys;
Bot euer when ony mon dude on-mys,
He wolde hit amend wt alle hure myȝt —
So graciose & so godelyche he was y-wys
þat hurre wylle was alle wrongus to a-ryȝt.
Ychemone & woman louede here fulle welle;
& wylde bestes & folys of flyȝt
To here clepynge wolde come fulle snelle

Bot dowuys of briddis he louede most

Suche virtuose werkus he wolde welle do

Ynam not sufficiant to wryte here alle;
Wherfore þeroff to speke ychulle steynte here,

For fulle parfite he was in herre leuynge,
& gret penaunce vpon herre he toke;
Bot euer he louede ouer alle thynge
To rede and syng vpon here boke.
And ofto he fast & lytull he ete,
& ȝet euery nyȝt he wolde vp ryse —
He faylede neuer bot ȝyff he were seke

A bedde he hadde ryȝt welle y-dyȝt
Wt ryche clothus of ryȝt gode aray,
Bot seldon he lay þere-in ony nyȝt,
Bot on an harde borde welle ofter he lay.
He went y-clothud fulle honestly
In ryalle clothyng to yche monus syȝt,
Bot an harde hayre fulle securlye
Was nexst here fleysshe both day and nyȝt;
þis hard hayre he wered hurre body nexst
Vnder a curtull of purpur byse
Enbroudrid wt golde, as saythe þe text,
Wt other clothus aboue þat were of gretter pryse.
Fulle honestlyche euer he went y-cladde
In blake clothyng, hurre ordur leyke,
Bot in gret mekenesse hurre lyff he ladde,
In lowe seruyse to euery mon, bothe hole & seke.
Bot seynt Adelwolde, þat holy mone,
Spake to þat mayde vpon a day
& sayde þat he herde neuer of non
þat went to Paradys one þat aray;
"Ny þy heuenelyche spouse, douȝter, quod he,
Delytede hym neuer ȝet in suche clethynge,Ms. clothynge?
Bot in lowenesse, in mekenesse & in charite,
& not in ryalte of clothus weryng."
þat mayde mekelyche ouswered hym þo
& sayde: "holy fader, vnder suche clothus of honeste,
ȝyf hit were plesyng to ȝov to take hede þerto,
Mowe ben virtwys werkus gret pleynte.
Fader, wher þe holy gost wolnot as gladlyche wone
Vnder a mantyl y-furned wt beuer ryȝt welle
And wt as gode wylle take þere his habitacyon,
As vnder a mantyl y-furned wt a row gotus felle?
Jhesu, holy fader, þat vs dere bouȝt,
Take not only hede to monnys clothynge,
Bot also to bothe his hert & þouȝt
& also to his gode worchynge.
Y chaue my lord god in my þouȝt as redy
& þenk vpon his gret passione both nyȝt & day
And wt as gode wylle y cholde hym seruy,
As þaw y were arayed in ryȝt pore aray."
When þis holy mayde had þus y-sayde
& mekelyche to hym þis tale y-tolde,
þis holy bysshop holde hym ryȝt welle apayde
& þonkede þerfore god mony a folde,
& lette þe grace of god wt-inne here worche
After his owne graciose wille;
Knowyng þat he loued better god & holy chirche
þen ony wordelyche ryche appayreylle,
& leuer he had, as þey trowedone ychone,
To sytte vpon a matte of þe Angoras

þen to haue ben duchasse, quene or Emperas. —
A Jhesu, what is mekenesse & lowenesse worthy
To euery mon and woman þat leuys here,
Seythe allmyghty god in heuene an heyȝe
Hath had hit euer in so gret chere!
Of alle þe virtwys þat euer mon wrouȝt
Mekenes is best & most worthy;
Wt mekenes god monnys sowle hath bouȝt,
By-cause of mekenes he was y-bore of owre lady.
þer nys non virtwe þat god louythe more
þen mekenes, whoso wolle take hede;
By-cause of pryde monnys sawle was lore,
Tylle goddus sone was for vs dede.
Wherfore we shulde loue hit most & lest,
Seythe hit is cause of alle honeste.
& þat god of alle virtwys louythe hit best,
By þis ensampulle ȝe mowe wel y-see
þat he preysede his owne modur ouer alle thynge,
As we redon in þe psalme of Magnificat,
For hurre mekenes & lowe berynge;
& for þat euer-lastyng worshepe he hath,
& bare þe sone of god most of myȝt;
Mekenesse was þe first cause þerof y-wys
þat he is made quene of heuene so bryȝt
& dwellud þere wt here sone in blys. —
So falle hit by þis mayden, seynt Ede,
þat mekenes & lowenes dud hurre so encresse
þat in hurre lyffe, as we done rede,
Gret miracles he dud þoro goddys grace.
Of þe whyche on ychull ȝov now telle,
þe sothe as y fynd in story y-wryte,Miraculum.
þe cas euery dele ryȝt as hit felle,
To ȝow þat lustenyth hit to wete.
A mayde he hadde in a tyme in here seruyse,
þat kepte hurre clothus, here chambur also:
þe whiche had brouȝt þat Abbay in to gret deseysse,
Nad god hym-self take hede þat tyme þerto.
For in a nyȝt hit fell þat tyme by casse
þat þe cerge þat stode bryngnyng þat auter by,
þis mayde toke hit þo from þat place
& blewe ouȝt þe leyȝt anone sodanly —
Bot þe weke hulte stylle þe snytte.
þis mayde heyȝede fulle fast þo a-way
& sodenlyche in to þat wyche hit putte
Wherenne seynt Edys clothys þo lay.
þe snotte fast brende, þe clothys cauȝt hete
& by-gonne to brenne ful fast.
þis mayde layde herre doune to slepe,
Bot sone after he rosse vp sore agast:
For when he begon to slombre & slepe,
þe flauour of þat feyre he tastede sone,
& vp he starte & begon to crye & wepe —
þe ladyes werone a-slepe þo euerychone.
þe feyre a-bouȝt þe auter gon brenne
Alle þe clothus fulle sone a-way.
þis mayde to þe wyche dud fast renne
þere as seynt Edys clothus þo lay.
þe ladyes a-wokon & reson vp fast,
þe feyre woxe euer more & more;
þe ladyes werone alle fulle sore agast,
For drede leste þey weron for-lore.
þey besedone hem fast þis feyre to quenche,
Euery lady wt alle hurrc myȝt;
Bot euer to god cryede þat wenche
To stanche þat feyre þat was so leyȝt.
þat wyche nasnot brende neuer a delle,
Bot þe feyre brende fast alle a-bouȝte.
Seynt Ede hurre-self he stod fulle stylle
& of goddes help he nad no douȝte;
Sayenge wt þe prophet on þis manere:
Bot ȝyff god hym-selff kepe þe cyte welle,
Cyte & keperus & alle y-fere
To nouȝt shalle fall euery delle;
& sayde: "lord god, ȝyff hit be þi wylle,
Stawnche þis feyre, lord Jhesu, y prey nowe þe,
At þyn owne lust, for þat is skylle,
þat alle thyng euer y-do be."
þo feyre staunchede þo after anone
þorow þe grace of goddus myȝt,
& more harme hit nathe not done,
Bot stanchede anone þo & left his lyȝt.
þis holy mayde stode & by-hulte
How hurre clothus lye vndur hurre fote
Among þe gledys alle by-swulte,
Bot he set not by þat leste a mote;
Bot onlyche on god was all hurre truste
& on his godenesse he þouȝt welle more
þen in alle þe toþer worldelyche burste
Or in ony oþer gode þat was þere lore.
Bot hurre mayde come forthe þo, sore wepynge,
When he sawe þat clothyng in suche aray,
Among þe feyre so leygynge

In doyng of masse, of derche, & of almys-dede,
& euer he was hurre-self in fastyng & in gret preyeris, y-wys,
& for hurre douȝter had algate gret drede.
& þus þis blessud womman, seynt Wultrude,
Suffrede for hurre douȝter long marterdam in þe abbay,
& of þe soule of þat holy virgyne hee hadde gret douȝte
& preyȝede for hurre continuallyche both nyȝt & day.
Bot afterwarde in hurre hert he was fulle gladde,
When he sawe so mony myracles y-do þere,
& þat so mony sekemen hurre hele þere hadde,
Of what monere sekenesse þat þey Inne were. —
Bot þis was þe furst miracle þat god wrouȝt after for þat mayde sake.
For hit byfelle þus in þe same thryddyþ daythryddyþ = thirtiethMiraculum.
þat he wt hurre moder þere spake,
þat a mayde-chylde was boron in þat contray.
Of rychesse þat childus frendus werone welle byfore,
And ryȝt gode lyuers þey werone also;
þey hadden preyȝede seynt Ede fulle ofte, þat, when hit were bore,
þat he wolde fouchesaue to be godmodur þerto.
þe fader and þe moder of þe childe þat day y-bore
Weron foulke of ryȝt gret astate y-wys
& haddone loued seynt Ede algate byfore
Alle þe tyme þat he alyue here one vrthe was;
Wherfore þey preyȝedon hurre þat trauell to do.
And he sayde þat wt gode wylle he wolde,
Ȝyff god wolde fouchesaue to consent þerto —
& ellus, he sayde, þat he do hit nolde.
Bot seynt Ede was dede forsothe byfore
And hurre soule fatte to heuene blysse
þe thrydtythe day or hite were y-bore.d in thrydtythe aus t corr. od. umgekehrt.
Bot ȝet þat holy mayde was þere þat tyme, y-wys!
For þe same day þat chylde was y-bore
þat seynt Ede wt Wultrude hurre modur spake.
& to þe Cathedralle-chirche of Wynchestre he was y-bore,
For seynt Alphege was redy þere þo for hurre sake.
For seynt Alphege was bysshop þere þo,
Nexte after seynt Ethelwolde bysshop þere he was,
Ychose by seynt Dunstone & by alle þe reme also —
For by a uysione seynt Dunstone was y-warnot of þat cas
þat Alphege, þat was Abbot of Bathe abbay,
Of Wynchester shulde bysshoppe y-sacrid be.
Wherfore he was y-preyd þat day
To cryston þat lytyl mayden-chylde so fre.
& when þe childe was to þat chirche y-brouȝte
& þe bysshop was redy þo þore,
& hurre godfader & hurre godmores, ryȝt as þey ouȝte,
Stode þere redy þe bysshoppe byfore:
þo þe bysshoppe cristenede þat childe fulle honestlyche,
As he welle couȝthe & ouȝte to do.
Bot in þe laterhende of þe office sodenlyche
Seynt Ede apperede hem bodylyche to.
For ryȝt as þe bysshoppe toke to hym þe serge wt lyȝt
& sayde: "haue þow, mayden, þis tapur brennynge,
þat þou mowe entre Inne wt god of myȝt
In þe day of þy weddynge"
& to þe childe þat tapur wolde han take,
Ryȝt as þe maner of holy chirche ys:
Bot seynt Ede was redy þere for hurre sake
& bede forth hurre honde y-wys;
þe lytulle childus honde he streyȝte forthe þo
To resayue þat tapre wyth þe lyȝt,
& þen toke þat tapre þe litulle childe fro
& in hurre owne honde he hulde hit forth ryȝt.
& when seynt Alphege had verylyche sey in syȝt
þat seynt Ede hurre-self was redy þo þere
To fonge to þe childe as he had y-teyȝt,
Ryȝt alyue as þaw he ȝet were:
Bot þo sodenlyche he vanysshede a-way,
Wt gret lyȝt & sote sauore y-fere;
& bodylyche apperede to hurre modur þat same day,
Sone after þat he hadde y-be þere.
& when seynt Ede was þus forthe-past
& alle þe seruys was welle y-do,
Seynt Alphege went þo in gret hast
Thedere as þat childus frendus were þo,
And tolde hem ryȝt as he had y-saye,
And chargede hem wt alle his myȝt
þat þey shulde neuer otherwys mary þat may
Bot onlyche to þe sone of god alle-myȝt.
& so þey dedon trewelyche after his redde
& brouȝtone hurre to Wylton after ful sone,
To lerne bothe to syng and redde;
& afterwarde to religione he was y-done,
& was blessud abbas in þat same place,
þe thryd after seynt Woltrude;
& of gode gouernele he had gret grace —
Hurre name was y-clepud Bryȝtwyde;
Bot twey ȝere ded he was by-fore
þe translacyon of þis blyssud virgyne seynt Ede,
& wt angels hurre sowle to heuene was bore,
Euere in ioy herre lyff to lede. —
þen from þis tyme forthewarde continually
þis blessud virgyne seynt Ede
In miraclus schewyng fulle bysyly (!)schewyng ist über einem radirten Worte (wrought?) überschr.
& ȝaff grace & hele to euery mone þat hurre bede;
So mony myraclus for hurre god wrouȝt
To euery mon þat ony nede hadde,
Of ony bone þat hurre ryȝtwyslyche bysouȝt:
He had anone what-euer he badde. —
Bot of on miracule now y chulle ȝow telle,Miraculum.
To all þat han luste to know and wete,
þe very trewethe euery delle
Ryȝt as y fynd in story wryte.
Hurre blessud moder, seynt Wultrude,
Toke a twaylle of ryȝt gode araytwaylle = towel.
& vpon þat virgenys tombe hit layde,
To hong þere both nyȝt & day.
þis twaylle y-bordryd abouȝt was
Wt palle þe mountenesse ofe han hondbrede:
Abouȝt þe tombe for honestnas
Hit was y-sowede in lengthe & brede.in lengthe über Rasur.
Bot þus hit byfelle vpon a day
þat a wommon, þat dwellede þere bysyde,
Come to þat tombe, hurre bedus to say;
& tylle al men were past awey, he dud abyde.
& when alle foulke weren þen ago
& he hurre-self alle-on was lafte,
Hurre holde custoum he þouȝt to do —Ms. custou.
For euer to stele was hurre crafte.
þis palle, enbroudryd wt golde so rede,
From þe twaylle ful sone he hit kytte
Wt hurre knyff in euel spede
& abouȝt hurre legg fulle fast hit knytte —
In monere of a garthur y-knytte hit was
Abouȝt herre leg, fulle preuely;
To stele hit þus preuely from þat place
Hee hurre by-þouȝt þus sotelly.
Bot when he had y-don þis dede
& wolde han ben past forth vpone hurre wey,ben st. hen?
He myȝt not passe ouȝt of þat stede,
He was y-trallyd in suche aray:
Hurre leygus weron fedryd wt hit so fast,
þat won fote myȝt he þennys þo go,won = one. Bl. schiebt not vor he ein, wohl mit Unrecht.
Bot wepe and cryede & hurre armys cast
& sayde "alas alas, þat me is wo!"
Bot þe sexsten come to hurre þo anone
And askede what sorwe hurre was,
And bad þat he shuld fast þenne gon
Home to hurre owne dwellyng-place.
Bot he myȝt not from þat place passe,
For no thyng þat he myȝt do;
Hurre leygus werone y-fedryd so fast,
þat he myȝt no fote þennys go.
& þo he tolde hem euery delle,
Wt mournynge chere & hert fulle sore,
Alle þe cas ryȝt as hit byfelle,
And cryede seynt Ede mercy & ore.
Bot when he had repentyd hurre þus
And byfore hurre iuge y-knowelachyd þis dede,
Ouȝte of þis thraldam y-delyferyd he wys,
And thongede god mekelyche & seynt Ede.
And þis goldene rebaunde was taken from here þo
& in to þe Minstre hit was þere brouȝt
& vpon an autre hit was þo y-do,
In memory of þis miracule þat þus þere was y-wrouȝt. —
þo of þis miracule hurre moder was gladde,
When he sawe verylyche þat hit was sothe.
Bot ȝet in hert he was a-dradde,
And to leue hurre preyerus he was fulle lothe:
& ordeynede ȝet þat euery day
Twey prestus shulde þere twey massus synge
Vpon þe auter by-fore þe whyche he lay,
Wt certeyne vrrysones for hurre prayng.
Dilexisti iusticiam, þe offyce was
Of þe ton masse, as yche vnderstonde;
þe toþer was Requiem eternam dona eis,
Preyng for euery soule bothe fre & bounde.
þus twey messus euery day he lette synge
Byfore hurre tombe at anauter y-wys,
Preyng euer ouere alle thynge
þat hurre douȝter myȝt haue heuene-blys.
Bot sone after þat worde spronge fulle wyde
Of þe myraclus þat for hurre þere do were:
For ichemone þat had ony sekenesse in þe contre þere bysyde,
Ȝyff he wolde come to hurre tombe, myȝt haue his hele þere.
For bleynde men hadden þere hurre seyȝt,
& crokette & maymotte fatton þere hurre hele —
Miracules weron do þere þus day & nyȝt,
& sekemen come þedur mony and fele.
Lepres men weron clansud mony one þere,
Frantyke men hadden þere hurre wytte —
Of what sekenesse þat ony mon inne were,
His bodylyche hele he myȝt þere feytte.
Of what maner diseyse þat ony mone hadde þo:
Ȝyf he wolde mekelyche prey to seynt Ede
And mekelyche in pylgrimage come hurre to,
He hadde þere help, or he þenne hede.
And when hurre blessude modur had knowynge of þis
And sey hit welle eueryday wt hurre hye,
He knewelle þat hurre soule was in very blysseknew well.
Wt othere blessud virgyns in heuene on heyȝe,
& thongede god wt alle hurre myȝt;
& fulle gladde in hert he was also,
For euery nyȝt he saw gret lyȝt
Aboute hurre tombe when he dud go.
Thredtene ȝere continually forsothe þere were
Gret miraclus at hurre tombe y-do,
& pilgrymys comen euere, bothe fer & nere;
& presoners ouȝt of presone weron lousede also.
& alle þe reme had gret ioy y-wys
Of þis blessud virgyn, seynt Ede:
For what þat euer was done amys,
He wolde hem help, ȝyff þey hurre bede.
Mo vertwys werkus forsothe he wrouȝt,
þis blessud virgyn seynt Ede,
For his loue þat hurre dere bouȝt,
þenne y con owther wryte or rede.
Bot byfore hurre translacione ychaue wrytone þis
þe wheche ychaue in storyus ofto redde,
þe very trewthe ryȝt as hit tys,
After my connynge, so god me rede.
And ȝyff ychaue ony thyng mys-do,
Discrete reder, y þe mekely prey
þat ȝe wolde fouchesaue to correcty hit soim Ms. ist þow radirt und ȝe überschr.
þat y naue no vyleny þere-by.
And alle þat fauerythe me in þis,
Y prey to god and to seynt Ede
Ȝeue hym grace to haue þe blys
þat Jhesu dwellyth inne yn hys godhede.
Amen amen for charite,
Prey we alle þat hit so be.

LG.L: þis blessud virgyn seynt Ede
Twolfe ȝere complete in hurre tombe lay,
As saffe, as hole as he vpone vrthe ȝede,
& gret miraclus wrouȝt bothe nyȝt & day.
Bot þe threttenethe ȝere, as ychaue redde,
Almyȝty god, þe kyng of grace,
Nolde let hurre body no lengur be hedde,
Seyth herre soule was in so ioyfulle a place.
Bot by visyon sende hurre brother to,
Etheldrede, þat was kyng of Englonde þat stounde,
& by visyon badde hym to Wyltone go
& takon vp þat blessed body ouȝt of þe grounde,
And sayde, þat body was worthy to haue grettore honour
Among vrthelyche peple in þis worde here,
Of þe whyche þe soule dwellythe vp in heuene-toure
Among þe virgyns & angelys so clere.
þis visyon þe kyng hym-self say firste,
& merueylede þerof meche in his thouȝte;
Bot to nomone þerof speke he ne dyrste,
Bot hulte hym stylle, as he nouȝt rouȝt.vor nouȝt ist ryȝt ausgestrichen.
Tylle hit come to þe thrydday —
For thre nyȝtys arowe he seyȝ þat same syȝt;Ms. urspr. seyȝe.
þen dudde þe Duke of Cornuayle to þe kyng say:
"Syre, y mette a merueylle sweuene to nyȝt.
Me thouȝt þat assemely lady come me to
þis same nyȝt thre tymes y-wys
& badde þat y chulde heyȝe & to ȝow go
& grete ȝow welle & say ȝow þys:
þat hit was goddus owne wylle seurly
þat þe body shulde be here in vrthe in greter honour
Of þe whyche þe soule was in heuene on heyȝe
Ychosyn in-to his owne heyȝe toure."
"For sothe, Ordulfe, quod þe kyng þo,
þis same sweuene verylyche mete y
þus thre nyȝtys arowe now last a-go,
And suche a fayre lady me þouȝt y sey,
þat badde me heyȝe to Wyltone for my suster sake,
Ede, þat was ded mony day a-go,
& sayde y shulde hurre body vp take,
& do hit gretter worshuppe he badde also."
Bot ryȝt as þuse twey princes talodone þisBl. taledon.
& gretlyche in hurre hert merueyldedone also,
A letter from seynt Dunstone to hem comen ys —
þe whyche was archebysshoppe of Caunturbury þo —
I-send by a worshipfulle knyȝt,
þe whyche hadde sey þe same visione also
Thre tymes byfore in won nyȝt,
Ryȝt as þe kyng & þe duke hadden y-do;
Certyfyenge þe kynge of his vision also
þe whyche he hadde y-sey wt his heyȝe,
How allmyȝty gode had send hym to
A messyngere from heuene an hyȝe.
þis messyngere was þat mayde seynt Ede,
þe whyche was sende from þe kyng of grace
Furst to hurre brother, kyng Etheldrede,
& nexte to syre Ordulf, þat duke of Cornuayle þo wase,
& nexte after to þat worshipfulle knyȝt
Of þe whiche y spake of here byfore.
Bot when þus thre wittenesse weron þus y-dyȝt
By þe blessud trinite vs lore,vs st. is.
þo afterwarde he come sone anone,
Bryȝtore þenne þe sonne in May,
To þis bysshop seynt Dunstone
& þuse wordus to hym dude say:
"Almyȝty god, maker of alle thynge,
þorwe mynde of his mercy & of his grace
Hathe take vp my soule to his dwellynge
In heuene into þat Joyfull place;
Bot ȝet hit pleseth to his benignite
To clarifye þat to monus hele here:
Wherfore to ȝow he hath send me,
Byddyng þat ze shulde my body vp rere.Ms. he st. ȝe.
In hast to Wylton he bytte ȝow gon
To parforme þe fette, of his owne wylle,
And take vp my body from þe vrthe anone
þat lyth þere, as þow leydyst hit, stylle,
To claryfy þe powere of goddus myȝt,
In to monnus hele & his hereynge:
For þere shulle be wrouȝt myracles day & nyȝt
þorw þe godenesse of heuene kyng.
& þat ȝe douȝt no-thyng of þis
Ny holde hit for no fantasy,no überschrieben.
Ȝe shulle fynd my body þere y-wys
As hole lygyng as euer aliue ȝe hit seye —
þe organys of þe lemys ouȝt-take
þe whyche childlyche y vsede when y was chylde,
As felyng and seyȝt ys from hem take,
From þe fyngers wt þe whyche y fedde bestes wylde.
Bot alle þe remanent of my body as hole hit ys,
Excepte þe organys of þe lemys þe whyche gouernede my wyttus fyue,
And as clene wt-ouȝt ony corrupcione hit is
As hit was whenne yche was on vrthe alyue.
& þe thombe of my ryȝt honde forthere-more
Ys as hole in fel & flesshe and blode,
Wt þe whyche y was y-wonde to blesse me byfore
Where-euer y went, sete or stode,
& also freysshe hit is to lokon now also,
As euer hit was in my lyff-day —
þe godenesse of god hath y-kepte hit so
& more better þenne y con ȝow now say.
Bot more for my fader gulte forsothe hit is
þat þe organys of my nother lemys ben take away,my nother = myn other (Bl. erklärt falsch nother = nether).
þen for ony thynge þat y dud my-self amys
Owthere by nyȝt or ellus by day.
Another tokon ȝe shull haue more þerto
þe whyche ȝe shulle redylyche se wt ȝour heyȝe:
þe vrthe þat my body lyȝt on, is mevyd, also,
Y-mevyd alle from þe grounde an hyȝe,
To shew welle þat my body is redy þenne to go.
& þat hit is hollyche goddus owne wylle,
þuse signus ȝe shulle se þere, & ȝet welle mo,
þe whyche y nulle not ȝow now telle."
& when seynt Dunstone had herde & sey alle þis,
& kyng Etheldrede hadde send hym letters also,
Towarde Wylton he toke þe way y-wys
Also blyue as he myȝt þederwarde go.
Bot syxscore myle to Wyltone he hadde —
For he dwelt at Caunturbury þo.
& fyue dayes iorneys he þederwarde madde
Ore he come Salysbury to.
And þe same nyȝt þat seynt Dunstone to Salesbury come,
He saw by vysione alle þat he saw here, & myche more, —here = ere.
& grettur credence to hym he þere nome
þen he dudde ony tyme þerby-fore.
For as sone as he was y-leyde y-wys
In his bedde þere to slepe,
Bot fullyche as-slepe ȝet he nys,l. a-slepe. nys = ne was.
When he þis sweuene dude þere mete.
Hym thouȝte þat he was at Wyltone þo
In þe chirche þere hurre body in tombe was,
And gret lyȝt hym þouȝt he sey þere, & angels to,
& seynt Denys, þat holy marter, stode in þat plase;
Bytwene þe tombe, hym þouȝt, þat marter þo stode,
Wt angelus & aposteles dignite,
Byfore þe auter fayre and gode
Y-halwyde in þe name of þe trinite.
He saw stonde among hem also
þat blessud virgyn seynt Ede,
þe whyche honestlyche spake seynt Dunstone to;
þat sayde, "lowe, syre, take ȝe gode hede!lowe = lo.
Fadur, ȝe knowel what hit plesithe god to do by me;
& for ȝe shulde knowe þe trewthe alle veryly,
God hath sende vs now hedur to þe:
For þis is þe expounder of goddus wyll þat stond me by."
Seynt Denys spake to seynt Dunston þo
And sayde: "brother, þe wylle of god is þys
þat ȝe take vp þys body & gretter worshippe do þerto,
Of þe whyche þe soule is worshippud in heuene blys;
For hit ouȝte welle to haue gret worshepe in vrthe here
þe wheche was keper off so clene virgynyte
And þe clene habitacyon of god also y-fere.
Go forthe, brother, & herre-of witenesse take of me!"
Wt þat seynt Dunstone from slepe a-woke
&, verylyche, trewe by-leue þerof he hadde þo.
And anone as hit was day, þe way he toke
Towarde Wylton, as fast as he myȝt go.
Etheldrede þe kyng, hurre brother, he founde þere þo;
& he tolde to seynt Dunstone his sweuene anone.
Ordulf, þe duke of Cornuaylle, & þe errelle of Dorsed also;
þey tolden hym hurre sweuenes euerichone.
þe bysshop off Wynchester, seynt Alphege, was þere þo,
Bycause of a vision þat he hadde y-sey þre nyȝtys byfore,
& þe bysshop of Wylton wt other prelatus mo.
& þere was rehersed þe miracle þat was do when Bryȝtwyde was bore.
& when þe kyng & þuse bysshoppus were gedered þus y-fere
& þis miracle rehersede byfore y-sayde,
Wt mony othur miraclus þat þere do were,
Þey wenton to þe Tombe of þis blessude mayde.
& heuyn vp þe stone & leyden hit a-syde,
þe vrthe also þey caston from þat plase away
& voudeden þat place, & made hit ryde,
Tylle þey þat blessud body hadden y-saye.
þey founde þo alle thyng sothe ysayde byfore:
& hurre blessud body alle-holle þey hit founde y-wys,y-wys ist nachträglich zugesetzt.
And a-rerede vp from þe grounde two fote & moretwo st. foure corr.
And alle redy to take vp forsothe hit þo was.
þis blessude body as hole þey hit founde
Ryȝt as alyue hit was goynge here y-wys,2565-8) sind unten a. R. nach|getragen.
& as sote a sauore come ouȝt of þat grounde
As þaw hit hadde come ouȝt from paradys.
& when þe kyng & þus bysshoppus thre
Wt other prelatus & lordus monyone mo
Seyen þat hurre body was as feyre, as hole, as bryȝt in ble
As hit was alyue when hit dude here go —
Excepte þe organus as y sayde ȝow ere:
As seyȝt and felynge weron y-taken hem fro
